Introduction to Length-Based Models
section: Introduction to Length-Based Stock Assessment Models
text:
Introduction to Length-Based Stock Assessment Models


Learning Objectives

 Understand why length-based models are used in data-limited fisheries.
 Learn the key inputs for the LBSPR model.
 Run a basic LBSPR analysis in R.
 Interpret the main outputs: SPR and F/M.


Why This Matters

 These are the most practical and powerful tools for your data.
 Provides a quantitative estimate of stock status.
 Directly informs management about fishing pressure.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
What is a “Fish Stock”?
Before we model, we must understand what we are assessing.

“

A group of fish of the same species that live in a particular geographic area and mix enough to share a common gene pool

”


Understanding the stock is the first step. The model’s results apply only to the stock we define.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Critical Assumptions


1. Stock Boundaries
Scientific Basis: The assessed population represents a self-sustaining unit with minimal immigration or emigration.
Practical Implication: Fish movement between regions must be negligible relative to population size.
2. Fishing as Primary Driver
Scientific Basis: Population dynamics are driven by natural mortality and fishing mortality, not by migration patterns.
Practical Implication: Changes in stock size reflect fishing pressure, not population shifts.

3. Representative Sampling
Scientific Basis: Length distributions in catches accurately represent the population structure.
Practical Implication: Sampling must be unbiased and cover the full spatial and temporal range of the fishery.






For This Training


We will assess yellowfin tuna caught in Somali waters as a discrete stock, recognizing this is a simplification that may require refinement for formal assessments.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Why Use Length-Based Models?
Many developing-nation fisheries lack:

Age-reading laboratories and trained personnel
Long-term catch and effort time series
Comprehensive biological sampling programs
Resources for expensive aging techniques (otolith reading)

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Advantages Length-Based Analysis

Length data is relatively easy and inexpensive to collect
Measurements can be taken dockside without specialized equipment
Large sample sizes are feasible with minimal resources
Well-established theoretical foundation







Core Assumption


The length distribution in your catch sample must reflect the length distribution in the exploited population. Biased sampling (e.g., only large fish, one gear type) will compromise results.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
What is LBSPR Model Framework
Length-Based Spawning Potential Ratio is a stock assessment model that estimates reproductive capacity under current fishing pressure.

Developed by Hordyk et al. (2015)
Based on equilibrium life history theory
Uses size-structured population dynamics
Validated across multiple species and fisheries

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
LBSPR Model Framework Model Outputs
Primary Metric: SPR (Spawning Potential Ratio)

Proportion of unfished reproductive potential remaining
Values range from 0 (collapsed) to 1 (unfished)
Directly comparable to management reference points

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Interpreting SPR Values








SPR Range
Stock Status
Management Implication




> 0.40
Healthy
Current fishing sustainable


0.20 - 0.40
Moderately exploited
Monitor closely, consider precautionary measures


< 0.20
Overfished
Urgent management action required

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Reference Points

Target: SPR = 40% (widely used globally)
Limit: SPR = 20% (conservation threshold)
These values may be adjusted based on species-specific characteristics and management objectives

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Key Inputs for LBSPR
To run LBSPR, we need two main things:



📊 Length Frequency Data: A representative sample of the lengths of fish caught from the stock.
🧬 Life History Parameters:

Linf: Asymptotic length (the theoretical maximum size).
MK: The ratio of natural mortality (M) to the growth rate (K).
L50: Length at 50% maturity.
L95: Length at 95% maturity.



These parameters can often be found on FishBase.org for your species or a similar one.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Parameters needed - 1 Biology



von Bertalanffy asymptotic length (Linf)
M/K ratio (natural mortality divided by von Bertalanffy K coefficient) (MK)
Length at 50% maturity (L50)
Length at 95% maturity (L95)




Code
MyPars@Linf <- 100 
MyPars@L50 <- 66 
MyPars@L95 <- 70
MyPars@MK <- 1.5

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Parameters needed - 2 Exploitation



Length at 50% selectivity (SL50)
Length at 95% selectivity (SL95)
F/M ratio (FM) or SPR (SPR).


If you specify both, the F/M value will be ignored.




Code
MyPars@SL50 <- 50 
MyPars@SL95 <- 65
MyPars@SPR <- 0.4

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Parameters needed - 3 Size Classes



Width of the length classes (BinWidth)
Maximum length of the sample (BinMax)
Minimum length of sample (BinMin)
Units for the length parameters




Code
MyPars@BinWidth <- 5
MyPars@BinMax <- 150
MyPars@BinMin <- 0

MyPars@L_units <- "mm"

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Interpreting LBSPR Output
The model provides three key estimates:

SPR (Spawning Potential Ratio):

The plot shows an estimated SPR.
It inform on the state of the stock.
A common target is 40% and a limit is 20%.

F/M (Fishing Mortality / Natural Mortality):

The estimated F/M ratio.
It tells us how intense fishing mortality is relative to natural death.
An F/M ratio > 1.0 suggests that fishing is causing more deaths than natural causes, a sign of high fishing pressure.

The fish state-stock:

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Key Takeaways

Length-based models like LBSPR are powerful tools for assessing data-limited stocks.
They require length frequency data and some basic life history parameters.
The key outputs, SPR and F/M, provide a quantitative snapshot of stock status and fishing pressure.
These results can directly inform management actions, such as deciding whether to increase, decrease, or maintain current fishing effort.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Questions & Discussion
Thank You

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Step 1: Prepare the Length Data
First, we need to process our raw data into the format LBSPR requires: a simple vector of fish lengths. We will filter for our target species group, “Tuna”, and remove any invalid length measurements.




Code
# Filter for Tuna and select the length column
tuna_lengths <- lw |> 
  filter(
    fish_group == "Tuna",
    !is.na(length_cm)
  ) |> 
  pull(length_cm)

# How many fish do we have?

tuna_lengths |> 
length()

# Let's look at the first few lengths
tuna_lengths |> 
head()

tuna_lengths |> 
  range()



It’s always a good idea to visualize your length data with a histogram before running the model. This helps you spot any potential issues with the data.


Code
hist(tuna_lengths, 
     main = "Length Frequency of Tuna",
     xlab = "Length (cm)",
     breaks = 30)

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Step 1 : Create LBSPR Objects




Code
MyPars <- new("LB_pars")




The LB_pars object has 25 slots.
Not all parameters need to be specified for the simulation model.



Code
MyPars |> slotNames()

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Step 2: Populate
Now, we populate the LB_pars object with key metric


Code
# Biological
# MyPars$Species = "Yellowfin"
MyPars@Linf <- 100 
MyPars@L50 <- 66 
MyPars@L95 <- 70
MyPars@MK <- 1.5 

# Exploitation

MyPars@SL50 <- 50 
MyPars@SL95 <- 65
MyPars@SPR <- 0.4

# Size Classes

MyPars@BinWidth <- 5
MyPars@BinMax <- 150
MyPars@BinMin <- 0
MyPars@L_units <- "mm"

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Step 3: Run the LBSPR Model
With our parameters and lengths objects ready, we can now run the LBSPRfit function. This is the core of the analysis, where the model fits the parameters to the length data to estimate the stock status.


Code
# Fit the LBSPR model
lbspr_fit <- MyPars |> 
  LBSPR::LBSPRsim()


The lbspr_fit object now contains all the results of our analysis.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
section: Step 4: View and Plot the Results
text:
Step 4: View and Plot the Results
The model provides estimates for selectivity (SL50, SL95), fishing pressure (F/M), and most importantly, the stock status (SPR).


You can view the key estimated parameters directly from the fitted object.


Code
lbspr_fit@Ests



The plotSim function gives a comprehensive visual summary of the fit


Code
lbspr_fit |> 
plotSim()

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Interpreting the Real Output
Let’s look at the plot from our lbspr_fit object.
!{fig-align=“center” width=“80%”}

Left Panel: Shows the fit of the model (red line) to your observed length data (grey bars). A good fit means the line follows the general shape of the bars.
Right Panel: This is the key result. It shows the estimated SPR (Spawning Potential Ratio). The black dot is the estimate, and the grey area is the uncertainty. You can compare this value directly to your management targets (e.g., 40%) and limits (e.g., 20%).

Based on this output, you can make a clear statement about the stock’s status.

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
Fecundity and Maturity Analysis


Learning Objectives

Define fecundity and maturity.
Understand methods for maturity staging.
Learn how to estimate Length at 50% Maturity (L50).
Recognize the importance of these parameters in stock assessment.


Why This Matters

Reproductive capacity determines a stock’s ability to replenish itself.
L50 is a key input for many data-limited models (like LBSPR).
Helps set size limits to protect spawning stock.

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
Key Definitions

Fecundity

The number of eggs an individual female can produce in a spawning season. It generally increases with size and age.

Maturity

The state of being reproductively active. We often classify fish as either “immature” or “mature.”

Length at 50% Maturity (L50)

The length at which 50% of the individuals in the population are mature. This is a critical biological reference point.

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
How to Determine Maturity
Maturity is determined by visually inspecting the gonads. A common method is a macroscopic staging scale.
Example 5-Stage Scale:



Stage
Description
Status




1
Immature / Virgin
Immature


2
Developing / Resting
Immature


3
Ripe / Spawning
Mature


4
Running Ripe / Spent
Mature


5
Recovering
Mature



In practice, stages 3, 4, and 5 are typically classified as “Mature” for analysis.

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
Estimating Length at 50% Maturity (L50)
We model the proportion of mature fish at each length class to find the length where that proportion is 0.5 (50%).
Step 1: Collect Maturity Data For each fish, record its length and maturity stage (e.g., 1-5).
Step 2: Create a Binary “Mature” Column Code individuals as 0 (immature) or 1 (mature).
Step 3: Fit a Logistic Regression Model This model describes the S-shaped curve of maturation probability.

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
Practical Example: Estimating L50



Yellowfin tuna (Thunnus albacares) typically range from 40-180 cm fork length, with peak catches occurring between 80-120 cm

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text: Length frequency

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
Key Takeaways

Fecundity and Maturity are fundamental to a stock’s reproductive potential.
L50 is a critical biological reference point that tells us the size at which fish start contributing to the next generation.
Estimating L50 requires collecting both length, weight and gonad maturity stage data in the field.
This parameter is a required input for many length-based stock assessment models you will learn about next.

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
Questions & Discussion

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Welcome to Module 6
Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites


Learning Objectives

Conduct hands-on data collection
Master field measurement techniques
Implement quality control in field
Work with fishing communities
Troubleshoot real-world challenges


Why This Matters

Theory meets practice at landing sites
Direct engagement with fisheries
Real data collection experience
Community relationship building
Evidence gathering for management

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Module 6 Structure
Three-Day Field Program:


Day 1: Setup - Site orientation - Equipment check - Community engagement - Training refresher

Day 2: Data Collection - Full sampling day - Hands-on measurement - Quality control - Data entry practice

Day 3: Analysis - Data review - Preliminary results - Discussion with fishers - Lessons learned

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Pre-Field Preparation
Week Before Fieldwork:


Confirm schedule with landing site managers
Brief community on data collection purpose
Test all equipment (scales, rulers, forms)
Prepare backup supplies (batteries, paper, ink)
Arrange transportation and logistics
Train any local staff assisting
Brief the team on protocols and safety

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Essential Field Equipment
Measurement & Recording:


Measurement Tools - Measuring board (marked 0-60cm) - Digital scale (0-50kg capacity) - Backup ruler (waterproof) - Calipers for precision - pH meter (for water) - Thermometer
Safety Equipment - First aid kit - Sun protection - Rubber boots - Gloves - Hand sanitizer - Insect repellent

Recording Tools - Waterproof forms (laminated) - Pencils (work when wet) - Clipboard with case - Backup paper & forms - Camera for documentation - Digital recorder
Data Management - Laptop/tablet - Mobile app (offline capable) - Backup power bank - USB drives - Data entry sheets

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Equipment Calibration
Before Every Field Day:
# Create calibration log
calibration_log <- tibble(
  date = Sys.Date(),
  equipment = c("Scale A", "Measuring Board", "Scale B"),
  last_calibrated = as.Date(c("2024-01-10", "2024-01-08", "2024-01-15")),
  status = c("PASS", "PASS", "FAIL - Recalibrate"),
  checked_by = c("Ahmed", "Ahmed", "Mohamed")
)

# Record in field book
cat(
  "EQUIPMENT CALIBRATION -", format(Sys.Date(), "%Y-%m-%d"), "\n",
  "Scale: [TEST WITH 1KG WEIGHT] - Result: ___kg\n",
  "Ruler: [MEASURE REFERENCE OBJECT] - Result: ___cm\n",
  file = "field_log.txt"
)

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Site Preparation
Arrival Procedures:
Checklist:






Note



Meet site manager/fisher representative
Identify landing area & vessel schedule
Set up measurement station (protected from weather)
Position scale on flat, stable surface
Organize forms and materials
Brief fishers on sampling procedure
Take site photos
Note weather conditions
Confirm contact information

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Fish Measurement Protocol
Standard Procedure:
Step 1: Species Identification
Before measuring, identify fish correctly

- Use ID guide provided
- Consult fisher if uncertain
- Record common name AND scientific name
- Note any unusual features
Step 2: Length Measurement
- Use fork length (snout to middle tail fin)
- Place fish on measuring board
- Read to nearest 0.1 cm
- Record immediately on form

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Fish Measurement (continued)
Step 3: Weight Measurement
- Use tared scale (zeroed before weighing)
- Place fish in weighing pan
- Wait for reading to stabilize
- Read to nearest 0.1 kg
- Record immediately
Step 4: Additional Data
- Sex (if identifiable): M/F/Unknown
- Maturity stage: 1-5 scale
- Condition: Normal/Injured/Diseased
- Special observations: Notes field

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Field Data Form Example
Standardized Format:
DAILY LANDING RECORD
Site: _____________ Date: _________ Observer: _________
Weather: __________ Vessel ID: _______ Effort (hours): ___

| Species | Length(cm) | Weight(kg) | Sex | Maturity | Notes |
|---------|-----------|-----------|-----|----------|-------|
| Tuna    | 45.2      | 12.5      | M   | 3        | Good  |
| Mackerel| 32.1      | 8.3       | F   | 4        | Damaged|
| ...     |           |           |     |          |       |

Total Fish Measured: ___ 
Total Landings Observed: ___
Sampling Rate: ____%

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Working with Fishing Communities
Building Trust & Partnership:


Explain the purpose clearly in local language
Show respect for fisher knowledge
Ask permission before photographing
Offer small compensation where appropriate
Share preliminary results with community
Thank fishers for cooperation
Return with findings later
Listen to concerns about management

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Communication in Field
Key Phrases (Somali):
English          →  Somali
Good morning     →  Subax wanaagsan
Thank you        →  Mahadsanid
What is this fish? → Kalluun yahan waxaa?
How many vessels? → Doonni yiman?
What time landing? → Saacada yahan?
Can I measure?   →  Miyaan tiri karaa?
Always:

Speak clearly and slowly
Use hand gestures
Have local assistant help
Repeat important information

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Evening Data Entry
Process at Accommodation:
# file: evening_data_entry.R

# Import paper form data
daily_data <- tibble(
  landing_date = Sys.Date(),
  species = c("Tuna", "Mackerel", "Shark"),
  length_cm = c(45.2, 32.1, 48.5),
  weight_kg = c(12.5, 8.3, 14.2)
)

# Run QC checks from Module 5
source('scripts/field_qc.R')
daily_data_clean <- validate_landing_data(daily_data)

# Create daily summary
summary_stats <- daily_data_clean |>
  group_by(species) |>
  summarise(
    n = n(),
    mean_L = mean(length_cm),
    mean_W = mean(weight_kg)
  )

# Save to backup location
write.csv(daily_data_clean, 
  paste0('backups/daily_', Sys.Date(), '.csv'))

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Troubleshooting Common Field Problems
Problem: Scale Not Working
Solutions: - Check batteries (carry spares) - Verify scale is on flat surface - Clean sensor with dry cloth - Use backup scale if available - Fall back to weight estimates - Recalibrate after power restored
Problem: Can’t Identify Fish
Solutions: - Ask the fisher (they’re experts!) - Take clear photo for later ID - Compare with ID guide carefully - Group as “Unknown” if unsure - Mark for follow-up verification

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Troubleshooting (continued)
Problem: Fishers Uncooperative
Solutions: - Explain benefits of monitoring - Offer monetary compensation - Involve community leaders - Choose different time of day - Work with local assistant - Emphasize sustainable fisheries
Problem: Too Many Fish to Sample
Solutions: - Sample systematically (every nth fish) - Increase team size - Sample during slower period - Pre-arrange larger monitoring team - Document sampling rate clearly - Scale up numbers using sampling fraction

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Safety in Field
Personal Safety Checklist:






Important



Let someone know where you’re going
Carry charged mobile phone
Avoid isolated areas
Wear visible/professional clothing
Work in pairs when possible
Know local emergency contacts
Respect local customs & regulations
Don’t accept rides from strangers
Keep valuables secure
Check weather before departure

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Health Precautions
Disease Prevention:


Before Field Work - Vaccinations current - Malaria medication - Travel insurance - Medical clearance
During Field Work - Wear gloves (cuts hazard) - Wash hands regularly - Use hand sanitizer - Avoid touching face

Fish Handling Safety - Watch for sharp spines - Avoid parasites - Be cautious with teeth - Don’t eat uncooked fish - Cover any cuts/wounds
Water Safety - Don’t drink untreated water - Be cautious wading - Watch for currents - Respect tidal patterns

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Site-Specific Considerations
Berbera Region:
- Large commercial port
- High landing volumes
- Mix of artisanal & semi-industrial
- Best in early morning (peak landing)
- Can get very hot
- Coordinate with port authority
Mogadishu Region:
- Variable landing patterns
- Urban setting
- Access may be restricted
- Security clearance needed
- Multiple landing sites
- Plan visits carefully

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Regional Notes (continued)
Other Regions:
Kismayo/Southern: - Remote location - Seasonal variations - Limited infrastructure - May need 2-3 day visit - Fuel availability varies
Borama/Northwest: - Semi-arid climate - Smaller landings - Community engagement essential - Water scarcity - Accommodation limited

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites

Three-Day Field Exercise Plan
Day 1: Orientation & Setup
Morning (2 hours): - Travel to site - Meet with site manager - Explain project - Brief on protocols
Afternoon (3 hours): - Set up measurement station - Equipment checks - Team training - Prepare forms & supplies
Evening: - Team briefing - Prepare for next day - Early rest

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Day 2: Full Data Collection
Early Morning (4 hours): - Arrive before landings - Calibrate all equipment - Greet fishers - Begin measurements
Mid-Day (2 hours): - Continue sampling - Data entry checks - Lunch & brief rest
Late Afternoon (2 hours): - Final measurements - Complete data review - Thank fishers - Pack equipment
Evening: - Data entry (all collected data) - Create daily summary - Identify problems - Plan Day 3

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Day 3: Analysis & Discussion
Morning (2 hours): - Quick field verification - Collect additional data if needed
Mid-Day (2 hours): - Data analysis - Create summary tables - Preliminary visualizations
Afternoon (2 hours): - Community presentation - Discuss findings with fishers - Gather feedback & observations - Schedule follow-up
Evening: - Final packing - Team debrief - Record lessons learned

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Data Analysis After Fieldwork
Evening Summary Analysis:
# Immediate post-collection analysis
field_summary <- daily_data |>
  summarise(
    total_records = n(),
    species_count = n_distinct(species),
    mean_length = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    median_length = median(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    length_range = paste0(
      min(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE), "-",
      max(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE), " cm"
    ),
    sampling_issues = sum(is.na(weight_kg))
  )

# Display to team
print(field_summary)

# Quick visualization
daily_data |>
  tidyplot(x = species, fill = species) |>
  add_bar(stat = 'count') |>
  adjust_title('Daily Catch Composition')

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Quality Assurance Program
Ongoing Verification:
# Compare measurements: Same fish, two people
comparison_data <- tibble(
  observer_1 = c(45.2, 32.1, 28.5, 41.3),
  observer_2 = c(45.1, 32.3, 28.4, 41.5),
  difference = observer_2 - observer_1,
  percent_diff = (difference / observer_1) * 100
)

# Target: <2% difference
comparison_data |>
  summarise(
    mean_diff = mean(abs(percent_diff)),
    max_diff = max(abs(percent_diff)),
    consistency = "PASS" # if mean < 2%
  )

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Welcome to Module 4
Data Processing and Storage


Learning Objectives

Transform raw data into analysis-ready format
Implement data cleaning workflows
Establish secure storage protocols
Create reproducible pipelines
Document data provenance


Why This Matters

Raw data ≠ usable data
Poor storage = data loss
Reproducibility requires documentation
Data governance enables sustainability
Efficient workflows save time & resources

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Data Journey: Raw to Insights
The Processing Pipeline:

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Stage 1: Data Collection & Entry
Field to Database:


Paper forms captured in field
Mobile apps with real-time sync
Excel spreadsheets maintained locally
Google Forms for simple surveys
Manual transcription (highest error risk)


Entry Quality Control:

Range validation at entry time
Dropdown menus prevent typos
Required field checking
Duplicate prevention

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Stage 2: Data Import into R
Reading Common Formats:
# Excel files
library(readxl)
data_raw <- read_excel('data_shared/raw_landings.xlsx', sheet = 'Section 3')

# CSV files
data_raw <- read.csv('landing_data.csv', stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# Google Sheets
library(googlesheets4)
data_raw <- read_sheet('https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/...')

# SPSS/Stata
library(haven)
data_raw <- read_sav('data.sav')

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Stage 3: Data Cleaning
The 80/20 Rule:
80% of analysis time is spent cleaning data
Common Issues:
# Inconsistent region names
data |> distinct(region)
# Output: "Berbera", "berbera", "BERBERA", " Berbera"

# Missing values represented differently
# NA, "NA", "", "N/A", "missing", -999

# Impossible values
# Length: -5, 0, 500 cm
# Weight: -2, 0, 10000 kg

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Cleaning Step 1: Standardization
Consistent Naming Conventions:
data_clean <- data_raw |>
  # Standardize region names
  mutate(
    region = toupper(trimws(region)),
    region = recode(region,
      'BERBERA' = 'Berbera',
      'MOGADISHU' = 'Mogadishu',
      'KISMAYO' = 'Kismayo',
      'BORAMA' = 'Borama',
      'BAIDOA' = 'Baidoa',
      'GALKACYO' = 'Galkacyo'
    )
  ) |>
  # Standardize species names
  mutate(
    fish_group = tolower(trimws(fish_group)),
    fish_group = str_to_title(fish_group)
  )

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Cleaning Step 2: Date/Time Processing
Temporal Data Handling:
data_clean <- data_clean |>
  mutate(
    # Parse date field
    landing_date = as.Date(landing_date, format = '%d/%m/%Y'),
    
    # Extract temporal components
    year = year(landing_date),
    month = month(landing_date, label = TRUE),
    day_of_week = wday(landing_date, label = TRUE),
    week = week(landing_date),
    
    # Validate dates
    landing_date = if_else(
      landing_date > today() | landing_date < as.Date('2017-01-01'),
      NA_Date_,
      landing_date
    )
  )

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Cleaning Step 3: Outlier Detection
Identifying Impossible Values:
# Define biologically plausible ranges
data_clean <- data_raw |>
  mutate(
    # Flag suspicious lengths
    length_flag = case_when(
      length_cm < 5 ~ "too_small",
      length_cm > 200 ~ "too_large",
      is.na(length_cm) ~ "missing",
      TRUE ~ "valid"
    ),
    
    # Flag suspicious weights
    weight_flag = case_when(
      weight_kg < 0.1 ~ "too_light",
      weight_kg > 500 ~ "too_heavy",
      is.na(weight_kg) ~ "missing",
      TRUE ~ "valid"
    )
  )

# Review flagged records
data_clean |> filter(length_flag != "valid" | weight_flag != "valid")

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Stage 4: Data Validation
Statistical Checks:
# Distribution review
data_clean |>
  group_by(fish_group) |>
  summarise(
    n = n(),
    mean_length = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd_length = sd(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    min_length = min(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    max_length = max(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = 'drop'
  )

# Check for implausible relationships
data_clean |>
  filter(is.na(weight_kg) & !is.na(length_cm)) |>
  nrow() # How many length but no weight?

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Data Storage Fundamentals
Storage Decision Tree:

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Option 1: CSV Files (Simple)
Advantages:


✓ Open format, no special software
✓ Version control friendly (Git)
✓ Human readable
✓ Easy to share and archive


Disadvantages:


✗ No data types enforcement
✗ Slow for large files
✗ No built-in backup
✗ Concurrent access issues


Best For:
Somali implementation with limited resources

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Option 2: SQLite Database (Local)
Advantages:


✓ Single file format
✓ Fast queries
✓ Data integrity constraints
✓ No server required


Disadvantages:


✗ Learning curve
✗ Limited concurrent users
✗ Backups manual


Setup in R:
library(RSQLite)

# Create connection
con <- dbConnect(SQLite(), 'fisheries_data.db')

# Write data
dbWriteTable(con, 'landings', data_clean, 
             overwrite = TRUE)

# Query data
data_query <- dbGetQuery(con, 
  'SELECT * FROM landings WHERE year = 2023')

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Option 3: Excel Workbooks (Moderate)
Structured Multi-Sheet Approach:
library(writexl)

# Create multi-sheet workbook
sheets <- list(
  'Raw Data' = data_raw,
  'Cleaned Data' = data_clean,
  'Daily Summary' = daily_summary,
  'Monthly Summary' = monthly_summary,
  'Data Dictionary' = data_dictionary
)

write_xlsx(sheets, 'fisheries_analysis.xlsx')
Advantages:

✓ Familiar to most users
✓ Can include metadata
✓ Easy to share

Creating a Data Dictionary
Essential Documentation:
data_dictionary <- tibble(
  Variable = c('landing_date', 'region', 'landing_site', 'fish_group', 'length_cm', 'weight_kg'),
  Description = c(
    'Date fish was landed',
    'Coastal region of Somalia',
    'Specific landing location',
    'Type of fish caught',
    'Fish fork length in centimeters',
    'Fish whole weight in kilograms'
  ),
  Type = c('Date', 'Character', 'Character', 'Character', 'Numeric', 'Numeric'),
  Units = c('YYYY-MM-DD', 'Text', 'Text', 'Category', 'cm', 'kg'),
  Range = c('2017-01-01 to today', 'Berbera, Mogadishu...', 'See lookup table', 'See lookup table', '5-200', '0.1-500'),
  Missing_Code = c('NA', 'NA', 'NA', 'NA', 'NA', 'NA')
)

write_xlsx(list('Dictionary' = data_dictionary), 'data_dictionary.xlsx')

Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Backup & Disaster Recovery
The 3-2-1 Rule:


3 Copies - Original - Local backup - Cloud backup

2 Media Types - Hard drive - Cloud storage - USB (offsite)

1 Offsite - Google Drive - OneDrive - Dropbox

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Backup Implementation
Automated Backup Script:
# file: backup.R
backup_data <- function() {
  timestamp <- format(Sys.time(), '%Y%m%d_%H%M%S')
  
  # Create backup directory
  dir.create('backups', showWarnings = FALSE)
  
  # Backup raw data
  file.copy(
    'raw_data/',
    paste0('backups/raw_', timestamp, '/'),
    recursive = TRUE
  )
  
  # Backup processed data
  file.copy(
    'processed_data/',
    paste0('backups/processed_', timestamp, '/'),
    recursive = TRUE
  )
  
  message(paste("Backup completed:", timestamp))
}

# Schedule weekly execution
# Windows: Task Scheduler
# Linux/Mac: cron job

Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Pipeline Automation
Complete Workflow Example:
# file: monthly_pipeline.R
# Runs automatically first day of month

# 1. Import new data
new_data <- read.csv(Sys.getenv('NEW_DATA_FILE'))

# 2. Append to historical
historical <- read.csv('processed_data/all_landings.csv')
combined <- bind_rows(historical, new_data)

# 3. Clean
combined_clean <- clean_landing_data(combined)

# 4. Generate summaries
monthly_summary <- generate_monthly_summary(combined_clean)
annual_summary <- generate_annual_summary(combined_clean)

# 5. Create reports
render_assessment_report(monthly_summary)

# 6. Backup
backup_data()

# 7. Log

text:
Welcome to Module 2
Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design


Learning Objectives

Design effective sampling schemes
Understand quality control procedures

Implement data validation protocols


Why This Matters

High-priority area from needs assessment
Addresses key implementation gaps
Directly improves data quality
Supports sustainable monitoring

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
The Data Quality Foundation
Why Data Collection Matters:


Poor data → poor decisions
Good protocols → reliable assessments
Consistent methods → comparable results
Quality control → confidence in findings


Module 2 Focus:
Practical, implementable protocols for Somali context

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Core Sampling Principles
Five Key Concepts:


1. Representativeness - Sample reflects population - Avoid biased selection - Random or stratified approach
2. Consistency - Same methods over time - Standardized procedures - Documented protocols

3. Adequacy - Sufficient sample size - Temporal coverage - Spatial distribution
4. Independence - Samples unrelated to each other - Avoid pseudo-replication - Account for dependencies

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Sampling Design Types
Stratified Sampling Strategy
Divide population into strata, sample from each:

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Sampling Approaches for Somalia
Option 1: Census Sampling
Sample every landing during monitoring period


Advantages: - ✓ No missing data - ✓ Highest precision - ✓ Detect all changes

Challenges: - ✗ High cost - ✗ Requires many staff - ✗ Logistically difficult

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Sampling Approaches (continued)
Option 2: Systematic Sampling
Sample every nth landing (e.g., every 5th fish)


Advantages: - ✓ Balanced coverage - ✓ Practical to implement - ✓ Moderate cost

Challenges: - ✗ May miss patterns - ✗ Requires discipline - ✗ Vulnerable to bias

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Sampling Approaches (continued)
Option 3: Random Sampling
Randomly select landings to measure


Advantages: - ✓ Statistically sound - ✓ Unbiased - ✓ Defensible method

Challenges: - ✗ Gaps in coverage - ✗ Lower precision - ✗ Requires planning

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Recommended Protocol for Somalia
Stratified-Systematic Approach:

Stratify by region (6 regions: Berbera, Mogadishu, etc.)
Allocate proportionally to landing volumes
Sample systematically within each region
Monthly rotations at sites to avoid bias
Document everything for quality control

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design

Catch Data Collection
What to Record:


Essential Variables - [ ] Date and time - [ ] Landing site/location - [ ] Vessel/fisher ID - [ ] Species/fish group - [ ] Total catch (count) - [ ] Total weight

Biological Data - [ ] Individual lengths - [ ] Individual weights - [ ] Sex (if identifiable) - [ ] Maturity stage - [ ] Condition assessment

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Quality Control Procedures
Five-Step QC Protocol:


1. Training & Standardization - Clear protocols - Hands-on training - Refresher sessions - Competency testing
2. Real-Time Checks - Verify as collecting - Cross-checks with partners - Outlier flagging

3. Data Entry Validation - Range checks - Logical consistency - Missing value detection - Double-entry verification
4. Statistical Review - Distribution analysis - Trend assessment - Comparison with history

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Quality Control (continued)
Step 5: Documentation






Important


Every data point needs metadata: - Who collected it? - When and where? - Under what conditions? - Any uncertainties? - Contact for questions?

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Common Data Quality Issues
Watch for These Problems:


Measurement Errors - Improper length measurement - Scale calibration issues - Rounding inconsistencies - Unit confusion (cm vs mm)
Procedural Errors - Skipped fish - Incomplete recording - Wrong species ID - Timestamp mistakes

Data Entry Errors - Transcription mistakes - Transposed numbers - Missing data codes - Format inconsistencies
Sampling Bias - Selective sampling - Non-random selection - Temporal gaps - Geographic avoidance

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Data Entry Best Practices
Digital Form Design:


Dropdown menus for categories (Region, Species)
Numeric validation (length > 0, weight > 0)
Date pickers for temporal data
GPS integration for location accuracy
Offline capability for field areas
Sync protocols for data backup


Recommended Tools:

ODK Collect (mobile)
Kobo Toolbox (cloud-based)
Excel with data validation
R/Shiny for real-time dashboards

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Data Cleaning in R
Essential Steps:
# 1. Remove duplicates
data_clean <- data_raw |>
  distinct()

# 2. Validate ranges
data_clean <- data_clean |>
  filter(length_cm > 5 & length_cm < 200,
         weight_kg > 0.1 & weight_kg < 500)

# 3. Handle missing values
data_clean <- data_clean |>
  filter(!is.na(species), !is.na(length_cm))

# 4. Standardize formats
data_clean <- data_clean |>
  mutate(
    landing_date = as.Date(landing_date),
    region = toupper(region)
  )

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
MODULE I
Fundamentals and Concepts

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Key Guiding Questions


What is sustainable fisheries management?
What is fish stock assessment, and why is it crucial?
Why is fish stock assessment important in sustainable fisheries?
Which fisheries to focus on for stock assessment?
How do assessment results inform policy, regulations, and conservation?
What are key requirements, challenges, and limitations?

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Key Guiding Questions (cont.)


Understanding inherent uncertainties in assessing wild fish populations
Ecosystem-Based Fisheries Management (EBFM): Managing beyond single species catch data
Integrating ecological, social, and economic considerations
Linking stock assessment to ecosystem management

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
What is Fish Stock Assessment?


A fishery stock assessment is the scientific process of:

Collecting data
Analyzing information
Reporting on fish stock condition
Estimating sustainable yield



Stock assessments are the backbone of sustainable fisheries management

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Data Sources for Stock Assessment


(1) Fishery-Dependent Data
Information collected from:

Fishermen
Dealers
Catch records
Landings data
Effort metrics








(2) Fishery-Independent Data
Information collected by scientists via:

Long-term research surveys
Scientific studies
Direct observation

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Why Assess Fish Stocks?


Determine Status: Evaluate current population conditions
Evaluate Management Actions: Assess potential impacts of regulations
Forecast Future Conditions: Predict stock trajectory
Define Benchmarks: Establish desirable conditions using abundance or biomass references

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Concepts: Life History


Age & Growth

Rate of approaching maximum size

Feeding

Trophic levels and strategies

Reproduction

Fecundity
Reproductive peaks
Life cycle patterns


Habitat

Habitat loss impacts
Water quality effects
Critical for management plans

Natural Mortality (M)

Critical parameter
Incorporated in population dynamics models

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Concepts: Population Dynamics
Recruitment

Number of fish surviving to juvenile stage within a given time period

Growth

How fish size and weight change over time

Mortality

Number of fish dying within a given time period

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Types of Mortality


Natural Mortality (M)
Deaths from natural causes

Fishing Mortality (F)
Deaths from fishing activity

Total Mortality (Z)
Z = M + F
Sum of natural and fishing mortality

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Concepts: Reference Points
Two Main Categories


Biological Reference Points
Based on biological characteristics of the stock

Exploitation Reference Points
Based on fishing pressure and harvest levels

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Exploitation: Yield Per Recruit
Understanding fishing pressure effects on cohort catch


Analyzes the catch obtained from a single cohort over its lifetime
Helps determine optimal fishing mortality rate
Considers growth, natural mortality, and fishing mortality
Key tool for evaluating fishing strategies

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Stock-Recruitment Relationship
How spawning stock size influences future recruitment


Links parent population to offspring survival
Critical for understanding population resilience
Helps predict future stock abundance
Informs spawning stock biomass targets

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Maximum Sustainable Yield (MSY)

The theoretical maximum catch that can be taken from a fish stock indefinitely without impairing its ability to replenish



Primary management target for many fisheries
Balances harvest and stock productivity
Requires careful monitoring and adjustment
May not account for ecosystem effects

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Overfishing: Growth Overfishing
Catching fish before they reach optimal size

Consequences:

Reduced total yield
Lost growth potential
Economic inefficiency
Smaller average fish size

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Overfishing: Recruitment Overfishing
Reducing spawning stock below sustainable levels

Consequences:

Insufficient recruits to sustain population
Population decline
Potential stock collapse
Long recovery times

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Summary


Stock assessment combines fishery-dependent and independent data
Population dynamics driven by recruitment, growth, and mortality
Reference points guide management decisions
Understanding life history is essential
Overfishing threatens sustainability
Ecosystem-based approaches integrate broader considerations

title: Fisheries Stock Assessment
text:
Questions?
Thank You

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text: The Concept

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
What Data Do We Need?
We generally categorize fisheries data into four main types:

Catch Data: How much is being removed?
Effort Data: How hard are we fishing?
Biological Data: What are the characteristics of the fish?
Abundance Indices: How is the population size changing?
Environmental Data: What external factors influence the fish?

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
1. Catch Data
Total removals from the stock over time (in weight or number).



Essential for almost every assessment model.
Sources:

Commercial logbooks
Port sampling / observers
Artisanal landing site surveys
Recreational surveys





Code
lw |> 
    mutate(
        season = month(date_dd_mm_yy), 
        season = if_else(season > 5 & season < 10, 'SEM', 'NEM')) |> 
    webr::PieDonut(aes(pie = season, donut = region), r0 = .5, labelposition=1)

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
2. Effort Data

Measure of the resources used to catch fish.
Crucial for understanding changes in fishing pressure.
Examples:

Number of fishing days (days-at-sea)
Number of vessels
Number of hooks, nets, or traps
Engine horsepower

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
2. Effort Data…
Spatial variation of fishing effort for longline and purse seine fisheries {.scrollable}

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
3. Biological Data

Describes the life history of the stock.
Collected through biological sampling programs.
Key parameters:

Length & Weight: For growth models (L-W relationship).
Age: From otoliths, spines, or scales.
Sex & Maturity: To determine size/age at maturity.
Fecundity: Reproductive potential.

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
Example: Length-Frequency Data







Example histogram of sampled fish lengths.

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text: Length Distributions

title: Data for Stock Assessment
section: Summary Statistics - Length Distribution by Fish Group and Region

title: Data for Stock Assessment
section: Summary Statistics - Length Distribution by Fish Group and years

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text: Weight Distributions

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text: Length-Weight Relationships

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
4. Abundance Indices

A relative measure of stock size over time (not an absolute number).
Used to “tune” assessment models.
Fishery-dependent: Catch-Per-Unit-Effort (CPUE).
Fishery-independent: Scientific surveys (trawls, acoustic, visual).

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
Abundance Indices…
Yellowfin Tuna Catch Per Unit Effort (CPUE)

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
Upwelling in TANGA-PEMBA
Seasonal upwelling influenced by EACC and the monsoon winds. Key characteristics include:



Seasonality
Nutrient enrichment
Ecological impact
Economic importance

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
5. Environmental Data
Environmental factors affect fish:

Distribution & Migration
Growth rates
Reproduction (spawning timing & success)
Mortality (survival rates)

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
Key Environmental Variables
These variables help explain changes in fish populations that catch and effort data alone cannot.


Commonly Used Variables:

Sea Surface Temperature (SST): Influences metabolic rates, growth, and species distribution.
Chlorophyll-a (Chl-a): A proxy for phytoplankton and primary productivity (i.e., food availability).
Salinity: Affects species tolerance and distribution, especially in coastal and estuarine areas.


Oceanographic Features:

Ocean Currents: Drive larval dispersal and create migration pathways (e.g., the Somali Current).
Upwelling: Brings nutrient-rich deep water to the surface, boosting productivity.
Climate Indices: Large-scale patterns like the Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) or El Niño (ENSO) that impact regional conditions.

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text: Seasonal Surface Ocean Circulation

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text: Seasonal Wind Circulation

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text: Seasonal Sea Surface Temperature

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
Sources & Integration

Data Sources: Primarily from satellite remote sensing (e.g., NASA, NOAA, Copernicus), oceanographic models, and research buoys.
Use in Assessments:

Explain variability in abundance indices (e.g., why CPUE is high in some years).
Improve recruitment predictions by linking larval survival to environmental conditions.
Define stock boundaries based on habitat suitability.
This leads to environmentally-explicit or ecosystem-based stock assessment.

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
Data Quality Considerations
The “GIGO” principle: Garbage In, Garbage Out.

Accuracy & Precision: Is the data correct and consistent?
Bias: Does the data systematically over/underestimate the truth?
Completeness: Are there gaps in the time series?
Standardization: Are data collected the same way over time?

title: Data for Stock Assessment
section: Data Limitations in the Indian Ocean
text:
Data Limitations in the Indian Ocean
Common challenges faced across the region that impact stock assessment.


Small-Scale Fisheries


🛶

 Dispersed, artisanal fleets are difficult to monitor comprehensively.

Multi-Species Catches


🐟🐠

 It is hard to separate catch data for individual species in mixed fisheries.

Limited Resources


💰🚫

 Low financial and human capacity for consistent, long-term data collection.

Transboundary Stocks


🗺️🐟

 Fish cross national borders, but data collection programs often do not.

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
Challenges in Somali Fisheries


Long & Dispersed Coastline


🗺️

 Many remote landing sites make comprehensive data collection difficult.

Historical Data Gaps


🗓️➡️❓

 Inconsistent records from past decades complicate trend analysis.

Logistical & Security Hurdles


🚧

 Accessing some areas for monitoring can be challenging and unsafe.

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
Opportunities in Somali Fisheries
Visualizing the key opportunities for enhancing data collection.


Community-Based Data


👥

 Engaging local fishers and communities to gather valuable, on-the-ground data.

Modern Technology


📱

 Using mobile apps and vessel tracking to improve data accuracy and coverage.

Regional Collaboration


🤝

 Partnering with neighboring countries and organizations to share knowledge.

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
Working with Incomplete Data
We don’t need perfect data to start! Data-limited methods are designed for these situations.

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
Strategies for Data-Limited Situations
When data is scarce, we adapt our methods to focus on what we can learn.


Use Proxies


📏➡️🗓️

 Use easily collected data (like length) to infer harder-to-get data (like age).

Borrow Information


📚

 Apply known biological parameters from similar, well-studied species or regions.

Focus on Trends


📈

 Analyze the direction of change (e.g., in CPUE or average size) over time.

Employ Simpler Models


🧰

 Use robust methods like Catch-MSY or length-based indicators that require less data.

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text: Coding with Programming languages (Python & R)

title: Data for Stock Assessment
text:
Somali Landing Site Data
Using the provided lw dataset from Somali landing sites:

Review the Data: Explore the length, weight, and catch data available for your assigned region. What are the main species? What are the temporal and spatial trends?
Identify Data Gaps: What information is missing? Are there gaps in time? Are certain species or gear types underrepresented?
Assess Data Quality: Look for potential issues like outliers, missing values, or inconsistent entries. How might these affect an assessment?
Propose Improvements: Based on your review, suggest 2-3 practical steps to improve data collection for stock assessment in your region.

title: Field Training at Kunduchi Landing Site: From Theory to Practice
text:
After several days of theory and computation in the classroom, the training moved to the field—where the real work of stock assessment happens. Participants traveled to Kunduchi Landing Site to apply their newly acquired knowledge to actual fish samples and observe data collection practices in real-world fisheries settings.





graph TD
    A["<b>FISH POPULATION</b><br/>Fish in the Ocean"] 
    
    B["<b>DATA COLLECTION</b><br/>Landing Sites & Fisheries"]
    C["<b>BIOLOGICAL PARAMETERS</b><br/>Growth | Mortality | Recruitment | Maturity"]
    D["<b>POPULATION MODELS</b><br/>Age-Structured | Length-Based | Surplus Production"]
    E["<b>STOCK STATUS</b><br/>Healthy | At Risk | Overfished"]
    F["<b>MANAGEMENT ADVICE</b><br/>Catch Limits | Regulations | Conservation"]
    
    A -->|Fishing| B
    B -->|Length, Weight,<br/>Maturity Data| C
    C -->|Parameter<br/>Estimates| D
    D -->|Analysis &<br/>Modeling| E
    E -->|Assessment<br/>Results| F
    F -->|Policy &<br/>Implementation| A
    
    style A fill:#e1f5fe
    style B fill:#fff3e0
    style C fill:#f3e5f5
    style D fill:#e8f5e9
    style E fill:#fce4ec
    style F fill:#fff9c4






The landing site visit represents a critical transition: moving from abstract concepts about population dynamics and growth parameters to the tangible work of collecting, measuring, and analyzing actual fish from the catch.



Field training participants at Kunduchi Landing Site practicing fish measurement and sampling techniques. Photo Credit: Herry Kelele




The morning’s field work directly connected to afternoon analysis sessions. Participants took the fish they measured and dissected, entered the data into R, and immediately saw:

How their measurements translated into length-frequency distributions
Whether they had correctly identified mature vs. immature fish
How data quality affected downstream analysis
Why consistent, careful measurement matters

This immediate feedback loop—collect data → analyze → see results → improve methods—is powerful pedagogy. When you see that your 1 cm measurement error shifts an L50 estimate by 2 cm, you never forget the importance of accuracy.



Several critical insights emerged from the Kunduchi experience:
1. Data Quality is Non-Negotiable
The most sophisticated models cannot overcome poor-quality input data. Participants witnessed firsthand how: - Measurement errors propagate through analyses - Inconsistent classification undermines maturity ogives - Missing data creates gaps in stock assessments - Investment in field training pays dividends in analysis reliability
2. Context Shapes Assessment
Landing sites aren’t uniform. At Kunduchi, participants observed: - Species composition varies by season and fishing effort - Vessel types target different size classes - Market demand influences which fish are landed - Social and economic factors affect data availability
This variability means stock assessments must be tailored to local conditions—generic approaches often fail.
3. Fishers Are Expert Observers
Conversations with fishers, traders, and fish handlers revealed invaluable knowledge:

“The big yellowfin have moved south this year”
“We used to catch more juveniles; now we’re seeing mostly adults”
“Effort has increased while catches haven’t grown”
“Certain gears catch different sizes”

Traditional ecological knowledge complements scientific assessment. The best management incorporates both.



Recording weight data in field notebooks. Photo Credit: Herry Kelele


4. Practical Constraints Are Real
Ideal stock assessments assume:

Regular, systematic sampling
High-quality equipment
Dedicated staff
Consistent protocols

At Kunduchi, participants learned to work within real constraints:

Limited budgets for equipment and personnel
Seasonal variation in landing site activity
Competition for fisher time and attention
Transport and storage challenges

Solutions must be practical, affordable, and sustainable in local contexts.



Dissecting fish for stomach content and maturity assessment. Photo Credit: Herry Kelele

title: Field Training at Kunduchi Landing Site: From Theory to Practice
text:
After several days of theory and computation in the classroom, the training moved to the field—where the real work of stock assessment happens. Participants traveled to Kunduchi Landing Site to apply their newly acquired knowledge to actual fish samples and observe data collection practices in real-world fisheries settings.

The landing site visit represents a critical transition: moving from abstract concepts about population dynamics and growth parameters to the tangible work of collecting, measuring, and analyzing actual fish from the catch.



Field training participants at Kunduchi Landing Site practicing fish measurement and sampling techniques. Photo Credit: Herry Kelele




The morning’s field work directly connected to afternoon analysis sessions. Participants took the fish they measured and dissected, entered the data into R, and immediately saw:

How their measurements translated into length-frequency distributions
Whether they had correctly identified mature vs. immature fish
How data quality affected downstream analysis
Why consistent, careful measurement matters

This immediate feedback loop—collect data → analyze → see results → improve methods—is powerful pedagogy. When you see that your 1 cm measurement error shifts an L50 estimate by 2 cm, you never forget the importance of accuracy.



Several critical insights emerged from the Kunduchi experience:
1. Data Quality is Non-Negotiable
The most sophisticated models cannot overcome poor-quality input data. Participants witnessed firsthand how: - Measurement errors propagate through analyses - Inconsistent classification undermines maturity ogives - Missing data creates gaps in stock assessments - Investment in field training pays dividends in analysis reliability
2. Context Shapes Assessment
Landing sites aren’t uniform. At Kunduchi, participants observed: - Species composition varies by season and fishing effort - Vessel types target different size classes - Market demand influences which fish are landed - Social and economic factors affect data availability
This variability means stock assessments must be tailored to local conditions—generic approaches often fail.
3. Fishers Are Expert Observers
Conversations with fishers, traders, and fish handlers revealed invaluable knowledge:

“The big yellowfin have moved south this year”
“We used to catch more juveniles; now we’re seeing mostly adults”
“Effort has increased while catches haven’t grown”
“Certain gears catch different sizes”

Traditional ecological knowledge complements scientific assessment. The best management incorporates both.



Recording weight data in field notebooks. Photo Credit: Herry Kelele


4. Practical Constraints Are Real
Ideal stock assessments assume:

Regular, systematic sampling
High-quality equipment
Dedicated staff
Consistent protocols

At Kunduchi, participants learned to work within real constraints:

Limited budgets for equipment and personnel
Seasonal variation in landing site activity
Competition for fisher time and attention
Transport and storage challenges

Solutions must be practical, affordable, and sustainable in local contexts.



Dissecting fish for stomach content and maturity assessment. Photo Credit: Herry Kelele

title: Field Training at Kunduchi Landing Site: From Theory to Practice
text:
Building Local Capacity

Sustainable Assessment Systems
The training is not about creating dependence on visiting experts. It’s about building local capacity for:

Data collection: Train-the-trainer programs where participants become data coordinators at their own landing sites
Analysis: Participants can now run their own assessments using R and the methods taught
Interpretation: Understanding what results mean for their fisheries and communicating with managers
Adaptation: Modifying methods to local conditions and continuously improving systems




Weighing fish samples at Kunduchi Landing Site. Photo Credit: Herry Kelele




Next Steps for Participants
When they return home, participants will:

Establish sampling programs at key landing sites in Somalia
Train local data collectors in fish measurement and recording procedures
Collect baseline data on species, sizes, and population structure
Conduct stock assessments using the methods learned in this training
Communicate results to fisheries managers and stakeholders
Support management decisions with scientific evidence

title: Field Training at Kunduchi Landing Site: From Theory to Practice
section: Conclusion: Science Meets the Real World
text:
Conclusion: Science Meets the Real World
The Kunduchi landing site visit exemplifies what makes this training distinctive. Participants didn’t just learn stock assessment in abstract—they got their hands wet, literally and figuratively, working with real fish, real data challenges, and real fisheries.
This experience bridges a critical gap in fisheries science education: the gap between what happens in textbooks and what happens in fisheries. When participants return to their landing sites and set up their own sampling programs, they’ll do so with:

Practical knowledge: They know how long measurements actually take, what equipment works, where problems arise
Realistic expectations: They understand constraints and can design feasible systems
Confidence: They’ve done it successfully once; they can do it again
Ownership: This isn’t an imposed external system; it’s their work, their data, their science

title: Field Training at Kunduchi Landing Site: From Theory to Practice
text:
Looking Ahead
The field training at Kunduchi is not the end of the program—it’s the beginning of the real work. Over the coming months, participants will implement what they learned, collect data from their own fisheries, and conduct assessments that will inform management decisions.
The impact of this training will be measured not in certificate holders, but in: - Fisheries stocks assessed with scientific rigor - Management decisions informed by evidence - Fishing communities protected by sustainable practices - Fisheries that remain productive for future generations
That work starts at landing sites like Kunduchi, where dedicated professionals measure fish and collect data one fish at a time, knowing that their careful work builds the foundation for sound fisheries science.

Special thanks to:

The fishing community and traders at Kunduchi Landing Site for their hospitality and collaboration
TAFIRI staff who provided equipment, logistics, and expertise
Somali fisheries professionals who brought commitment and enthusiasm to the field work
All participants who demonstrated remarkable patience and attention to detail in learning these critical skills

title: Somali Fisheries Stock Assessment Training
text:
This training program equips fisheries professionals with essential knowledge and practical skills for conducting stock assessments. Designed specifically for the Somali context, the course bridges scientific principles with real-world applications in data-limited environments.






Important



Target Audience: Fisheries scientists, managers, and policy makers seeking to improve stock assessment capacity in East African fisheries.

title: Somali Fisheries Stock Assessment Training
text:
This training program equips fisheries professionals with essential knowledge and practical skills for conducting stock assessments. Designed specifically for the Somali context, the course bridges scientific principles with real-world applications in data-limited environments.






Important



Target Audience: Fisheries scientists, managers, and policy makers seeking to improve stock assessment capacity in East African fisheries.

title: Somali Fisheries Stock Assessment Training
text:
Course Modules


Module 1: Fundamentals of Fish Stock Assessment
Core concepts in fisheries science, biological parameters, and population dynamics. Establish the scientific foundation for all assessment work.


Module 2: Fisheries Data Types
Essential data collection methods, quality assurance, and working with incomplete datasets common in the Indian Ocean.


Module 3: Length-Based Assessment Methods
Practical approaches for stocks with limited age data, using length frequency distributions and simple indicators.


Module 4: Catch-MSY and Empirical Methods
Data-limited approaches suitable for data-poor fisheries, with applications to Somali stocks.


Module 5: Integrated Stock Assessment Models
Introduction to age-structured models and integrated assessment frameworks for well-studied stocks.


Module 6: Assessment Communication & Management Strategy Evaluation
Presenting results to decision-makers and evaluating management options using assessment outputs.

title: Somali Fisheries Stock Assessment Training
text:
Learning Approach

Evidence-Based: Grounded in FAO guidelines and international best practices
Hands-On: Practical activities using R and specialist fisheries software
Context-Specific: Case studies from Indian Ocean fisheries
Flexible: Modules designed for self-paced or group learning

title: Somali Fisheries Stock Assessment Training
text:
Getting Started
Begin with Module 1: Fundamentals

Course Duration: 6 weeks | Format: Self-paced with group discussions | Language: English

title: Determination Size at Maturity
text:
What we’re doing: Load the R packages required for maturity analysis and data visualization.
Code
# Load required libraries
library(tidyverse)      # Data manipulation and visualization
library(sizeMat)        # For morphological maturity analysis
library(gt)             # For professional tables
require(TropFishR)      # Tropical fisheries methods (if needed)

title: Determination Size at Maturity
text:
Data Preparation
What we’re doing: Load the fisheries dataset containing length and weight measurements for various fish species.


Code
lw = read_csv("lw2.csv")



Identify Species with Sufficient Data
What we’re doing: Filter for fish species with at least 200 recorded individuals to ensure statistical reliability.
Why it matters: Species with few observations produce unreliable estimates. Focusing on well-sampled species ensures robust maturity determinations.


Code
fishes = lw |> 
  group_by(fish_type_code) |> 
  tally() |> 
  arrange(desc(n)) |> 
  filter(n > 200) |> 
  pull(fish_type_code)

title: Determination Size at Maturity
text:
Fish Groups Analysis
In the following sections, we will perform the size-at-maturity analysis for several key tuna and mackerel species. For each species, we: 1. Filter the data to that species 2. Classify fish as mature or immature using morphological criteria 3. Model the maturity ogive to estimate L50 (length at 50% maturity)

Yellowfin Tuna
What we’re doing: Filter the dataset to create a subset containing only Yellowfin Tuna (YFT).
Why start here: Yellowfin is a well-studied, commercially important species with good sample sizes.


Code
yft = lw |> 
    filter(fish_type_code == 'YFT')




Maturity Classification using Linear Discriminant Analysis
What we’re doing: Use the classify_mature() function to separate fish into mature and immature groups based on their length-weight relationship.
How it works: - Linear discriminant analysis (LDA) finds the boundary that best separates mature from immature fish in length-weight space - Creates a new mature column indicating classification for each fish - Works best when there’s a clear separation between groups in the data
Why it matters: This classification is the foundation for the subsequent ogive fitting and L50 estimation.


Code
## Partitioning with Linear Discriminant Analysis
classified_yft <- yft |> 
  classify_mature(
    varNames = c("length_cm", "weight_kg"),  # Variables to use for classification
    varSex = NULL,                            # No sex data available
    selectSex = NULL,
    method = "ld"                             # Linear discriminant method
  )


all individuals were used in the analysis 


Code
classified_yft

Number in adult group = 94

Call:
glm(formula = y ~ x, data = juv)

(Intercept) -7.322622   0.461709  -15.86   <2e-16 ***
x            0.197443   0.006518   30.29   <2e-16 ***

AIC: 1430

x             0.82557    0.05265   15.68   <2e-16 ***

               Estimate Std. Error    t value     Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept)  -7.3226224 1.54018587  -4.754376 2.644698e-06
x             0.1974434 0.02174360   9.080530 2.922047e-18

x:mature      0.6281301 0.03244821  19.357928 6.044495e-62
[1] "slopes are different"




Visualize Classification Results
What we’re doing: Plot the classified fish on a length-weight scatter plot to visually inspect classification quality.
What to look for: - Clear spatial separation between mature (upper right) and immature (lower left) groups - Few misclassified points in the overlap region - Good coverage of the entire range


Code
classified_yft |> 
  plot(
    main = 'Maturity Classification: Yellowfin Tuna',
    xlab = 'Length (cm)', 
    ylab = 'Weight (kg)',
    cex.main = 1.5,
    cex.lab = 1.2,
    cex.axis = 1
  )











Fit Maturity Ogive
What we’re doing: Model the maturity classification with a logistic regression curve using 1000 bootstrap samples.
What this produces: - A smooth S-shaped (logistic) curve showing proportion mature at each length - Estimates of L50 (length at 50% maturity) and L95 (length at 95% maturity) - Bootstrap confidence intervals around these estimates
Why 1000 iterations: Bootstrap resampling with 1000 iterations provides stable estimates and quantifies uncertainty in L50.


Code
yft_ogive_fq <- classified_yft |> 
  morph_mature(
    method = "fq",      # Frequentist method using logistic regression
    niter = 1000        # 1000 bootstrap samples for stable estimates
  )




Plot Maturity Ogive
What we’re doing: Display the fitted maturity curve showing the proportion of mature fish at each length.
What it shows: - X-axis: Length (cm) - Y-axis: Proportion of mature individuals (0 to 1) - S-shaped curve typical of logistic maturity schedules - L50 is where the curve crosses 0.5 (50% maturity)


Code
yft_ogive_fq |> 
    plot(
    main = 'Maturity Ogive: Yellowfin Tuna',
    xlab = 'Length (cm)', 
    ylab = 'Proportion Mature',
    cex.main = 1.5,
    cex.lab = 1.2,
    cex.axis = 1, 
    onlyOgive = TRUE
  )









Size at morphometric maturity = 94.3 
Confidence intervals = 92.4 - 96.5 
Rsquare = 0.89

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
Fecundity and Maturity Analysis


Learning Objectives

Define fecundity and maturity.
Understand methods for maturity staging.
Learn how to estimate Length at 50% Maturity (L50).
Recognize the importance of these parameters in stock assessment.


Why This Matters

Reproductive capacity determines a stock’s ability to replenish itself.
L50 is a key input for many data-limited models (like LBSPR).
Helps set size limits to protect spawning stock.

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
Key Definitions

Fecundity

The number of eggs an individual female can produce in a spawning season. It generally increases with size and age.

Maturity

The state of being reproductively active. We often classify fish as either “immature” or “mature.”

Length at 50% Maturity (L50)

The length at which 50% of the individuals in the population are mature. This is a critical biological reference point.

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
How to Determine Maturity
Maturity is determined by visually inspecting the gonads. A common method is a macroscopic staging scale.
Example 5-Stage Scale:



Stage
Description
Status




1
Immature / Virgin
Immature


2
Developing / Resting
Immature


3
Ripe / Spawning
Mature


4
Running Ripe / Spent
Mature


5
Recovering
Mature



In practice, stages 3, 4, and 5 are typically classified as “Mature” for analysis.

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
Estimating Length at 50% Maturity (L50)
We model the proportion of mature fish at each length class to find the length where that proportion is 0.5 (50%).
Step 1: Collect Maturity Data For each fish, record its length and maturity stage (e.g., 1-5).
Step 2: Create a Binary “Mature” Column Code individuals as 0 (immature) or 1 (mature).
Step 3: Fit a Logistic Regression Model This model describes the S-shaped curve of maturation probability.

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
Practical Example: Estimating L50



Yellowfin tuna (Thunnus albacares) typically range from 40-180 cm fork length, with peak catches occurring between 80-120 cm

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis
text:
Key Takeaways

Fecundity and Maturity are fundamental to a stock’s reproductive potential.
L50 is a critical biological reference point that tells us the size at which fish start contributing to the next generation.
Estimating L50 requires collecting both length, weight and gonad maturity stage data in the field.
This parameter is a required input for many length-based stock assessment models you will learn about next.

title: Fecundity and Maturity Analysis

Questions & Discussion
Thank You

title: Stock Assessment Using LBSPR
text:
This document provides a step-by-step guide to performing a stock assessment simulation using the Length-Based Spawning Potential Ratio (LBSPR) method. LBSPR is a powerful technique for assessing the health of fish stocks, especially in data-limited situations where traditional age-based data is unavailable.
We will first simulate a fish population with known biological and fishery characteristics to understand how the LBSPR model works. This simulation will generate an expected length-frequency distribution, which can later be compared against real-world data collected from fisheries.

title: Stock Assessment Using LBSPR
text:
This document provides a step-by-step guide to performing a stock assessment simulation using the Length-Based Spawning Potential Ratio (LBSPR) method. LBSPR is a powerful technique for assessing the health of fish stocks, especially in data-limited situations where traditional age-based data is unavailable.
We will first simulate a fish population with known biological and fishery characteristics to understand how the LBSPR model works. This simulation will generate an expected length-frequency distribution, which can later be compared against real-world data collected from fisheries.

title: Stock Assessment Using LBSPR
text:
Setting Up the R Environment
The first step is to load the necessary R packages. Each package provides a specific set of tools required for our analysis.

tidyverse: A collection of R packages for data manipulation and visualization.
LBSPR: The core package for this analysis, containing all functions for the LBSPR method.
TropFishR: A package for tropical fish stock assessment, which can be useful for related analyses.
gt: For creating beautiful and presentation-ready tables.
sizeMat: A package for estimating size at maturity, a key input for LBSPR.



Code
# Load required libraries
require(tidyverse) # Data manipulation and visualization
require(tidyplots) # Easy plotting
require(LBSPR)     # Length-Based Spawning Potential Ratio analysis
require(sizeMat)   # Estimate size at maturity
require(gt)        # Create presentation-ready tables
require(TropFishR) # Tropical fisheries stock assessment methods

title: Stock Assessment Using LBSPR
text:
Read data
The first step in any data analysis is to load the data. Our fisheries data, containing length, weight, species, and catch information, is stored in a CSV (Comma-Separated Values) file named lw2.csv. The following code chunk reads this file into our R environment and stores it in a data frame called lw. This data frame will be the foundation for all subsequent steps in our stock assessment.


Code
lw = read_csv("lw2.csv")



Model Fish Group: Yellowfin Tuna
What we’re doing: We need to isolate data for a single species to conduct a stock-specific assessment. Here we filter for Yellowfin Tuna (YFT) from the larger dataset.
Why it matters: Each fish species has different growth rates, maturity schedules, and fishing characteristics. By focusing on one species, we can accurately estimate its population parameters.


Code
yft = lw |> 
    filter(fish_type_code == 'YFT')




Explore Length-Weight Relationship
What we’re doing: We create a scatter plot showing how length and weight relate to each other for Yellowfin Tuna across different regions, with a fitted curve.
What to look for:

A smooth, curved relationship indicates normal growth patterns
Outliers might represent data entry errors
Different regions may show different growth patterns



Code
yft |> 
  tidyplot(x = length_cm, y = weight_kg, color = region) |> 
  add_data_points() |> 
  add_curve_fit() |> 
  adjust_size(width = 2, height = 3, unit = 'in') |> 
  adjust_font(fontsize = 12) |> 
  adjust_legend_position(position = c(.35, .9)) |> 
  adjust_x_axis(title = 'Length (cm)') |> 
  adjust_y_axis(title = 'Weight (kg)') |> 
  remove_legend_title()











Data Quality Filter
What we’re doing: Remove potentially problematic data points (fish from Berbera region and very small fish under 20 cm).
Why it matters:

Small fish may be juveniles with different growth patterns
Regional data quality issues may affect estimates
Cleaner data = more reliable assessment results



Code
yft = lw |> 
    filter(fish_type_code == 'YFT' & !region == 'Berbera' & length_cm > 20)




Maturity Classification
What we’re doing: Separate fish into two groups—mature (able to reproduce) and immature (not yet reproductive)—using statistical analysis of length and weight patterns.
Why it matters: Maturity schedules are critical for LBSPR because:

The model needs to know at what size fish can first reproduce (L50)
Fishing immature fish reduces population recovery ability
Management often protects immature fish to ensure stock replenishment



Code
## Partitioning with Frequentist regression 
classified_yft <- yft |> 
  classify_mature(
    varNames = c("length_cm", "weight_kg"),
    varSex = NULL, 
    selectSex = NULL,
    method = "ld"
  )


all individuals were used in the analysis 


Code
classified_yft

Visualize Maturity Classification
What we’re doing: Plot the classified mature and immature fish to visually inspect the separation quality.
What to look for: Clear separation between mature (upper right) and immature (lower left) fish groups indicates good classification.


Code
classified_yft |> 
  plot(
    xlab = 'Length (cm)', 
    ylab = 'Weight (kg)',
    cex.main = 1.5,
    cex.lab = 1.5,
    cex.axis = 1.3, 
    las = 1
  )











Estimate L50 (Length at 50% Maturity)
What we’re doing: Calculate the length at which 50% of the population reaches maturity using a logistic regression fitted to 1000 bootstrap samples.
Why it matters: L50 is a key input to LBSPR because it defines when fish become vulnerable to overfishing from a reproductive standpoint.


Code
yft_ogive_fq <- classified_yft |> 
  morph_mature(
    method = "fq", 
    niter = 1000
)




Display Maturity Parameters
What we’re doing: Create a professional table showing the estimated parameters of the maturity curve (A, B intercepts and L50).
What the columns mean:

A & B: Parameters of the logistic maturity curve
L50: Length (cm) where 50% of fish are mature
R²: How well the curve fits the data (1.0 = perfect fit)



Code
yft_ogive_fq |> 
    print() |> 
    as.data.frame() |> 
    as_tibble() |> 
    mutate(Freq = as.numeric(Freq)) |> 
    pivot_wider(names_from = Var1 , values_from  = Freq) |> 
    gt() |> 
    fmt_number(columns = everything(), decimals = 2) |> 
    fmt_missing(columns = everything(), missing_text = '-') |> 
    cols_label(
        Var2 ~ 'Variables',
        # A ~ 'A-Intercept',
        # B ~ 'B-Slope',
        L50 ~ md('L~50~'),
        R2  ~ md('R^2^')
    ) |>
    tab_spanner(columns = c('A', 'B'), label = 'Ogive Parameters') |> 
    tab_options(data_row.padding = px(5), table.font.size = '12pt') |> 
    cols_width(
        Var2 ~ px(200),
        A ~ px(120),
        B ~ px(70),
        L50 ~ px(70),
        R2 ~ px(70)
    ) |> 
    tab_footnote(footnote = 'A for Intercept of the logistic curve.', locations = cells_column_labels(columns = 'A'))|> 
    tab_footnote(footnote = 'B for slope of the logistic curve.', locations = cells_column_labels(columns = 'B'))

1 A for Intercept of the logistic curve.
