text:
Welcome to Module 1
Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts


Learning Objectives

Understand core stock assessment principles
Identify different data types used in assessments
Apply concepts to real Somali fisheries data
Build foundation for advanced methods


Why This Matters

Essential for evidence-based management
Reinforces foundational knowledge
Prepares for data-limited methods
Supports sustainable fisheries

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
What is Stock Assessment?
Stock assessment is the scientific process of estimating the status and productivity of fish populations to inform management decisions.
Key Components:


Population Dynamics: How fish populations change over time
Catch Data: What we remove from the stock
Biological Data: Growth, reproduction, mortality
Environmental Context: Habitat and external factors

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text: The Assessment Cycle

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
section: Types of Data in Stock Assessment
text:
Types of Data in Stock Assessment
Primary Data Categories:


Catch Data - Total landings (numbers or weight) - Species composition - Temporal patterns - Geographic distribution

Biological Data - Size distributions - Age/length structure - Growth rates - Maturity information

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Types of Data (continued)


Effort Data - Number of vessels/fishers - Fishing days - Landing site activity - Spatial distribution

Environmental Data - Oceanographic conditions - Habitat quality - Seasonal patterns - Climate factors

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Case Study: Somali Fisheries Data
What We Have in Our Dataset:


Landing records: 3,571 specimens across 6 regions
Species groups: Tuna, Mackerel, Shark, Jacks, Billfish, Rays & Skates
Time series: 2017-2023 (7 years of data)
Biological measurements: Length (cm) and Weight (kg)
Geographic coverage: Berbera, Borama, Mogadishu, Kismayo, Baidoa, Galkacyo

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Key Indicators from Our Data
CPUE (Catch Per Unit Effort)
Specimens caught per landing site per year


What it tells us: - Stock abundance trends - Fishing pressure changes - Sustainability signals

Warning signs: - ⚠️ Declining CPUE = potential overfishing - ✓ Stable CPUE = sustainable harvest

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Key Indicators: Size Structure
Average Fish Size Trends


Healthy stocks: Stable or increasing average size
Overfished stocks: Declining average size over time
Young populations: Smaller specimens dominate
Mature populations: Mix of sizes present


Why Size Matters:
Smaller fish = fewer breeding adults = recruitment problems

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Key Indicators: Species Diversity
Shannon Diversity Index
Measures ecosystem stability:


High Diversity - Many species equally represented - Ecosystem resilience - Lower collapse risk - Adaptable to changes

Low Diversity - Few dominant species - Ecosystem vulnerability - High collapse risk - Susceptible to shifts

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Key Indicators: Seasonal Patterns
Why Seasonality Matters:


Peak seasons: When stocks are most vulnerable
Off-season monitoring: Essential for baseline data
Breeding seasons: Critical conservation periods
Nomadic patterns: Species movement and migration


Somalia’s Monsoon Seasons:

NEM (Nov-May): Northeast Monsoon
SEM (Jun-Sep): Southwest Monsoon

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Stock Status Assessment Framework
Traffic Light System:


Green ✓ - CPUE stable - Size structure healthy - High diversity - Sustainable

Yellow ⚠️ - CPUE declining - Size shrinking - Diversity moderate - Caution needed

Red ✗ - CPUE low - Size very small - Low diversity - Urgent action

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Applying This to Somali Data
Our Findings Show:


Regional differences: Some areas more productive than others
Temporal trends: Changes over 2017-2023 period
Species-specific patterns: Different groups show different trends
Seasonal variability: Predictable patterns across years

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Data Quality Matters
Good Data Requires:


Collection Standards - Consistent methods - Regular sampling - Complete records - Training & protocols

Quality Control - Data verification - Error detection - Outlier assessment - Metadata documentation

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Welcome to Module 3
Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods


Learning Objectives

Use empirical indicators for status
Conduct practical R-based analyses
Make evidence-based recommendations


Why This Matters

Most requested training component
Lowest expertise area identified
Directly applicable to Somali data
Actionable for decision-makers

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
What Are Data-Limited Methods?
Stock assessments when you have:


What You DON’T Have: - ✗ Age structure data - ✗ Long time series - ✗ Detailed catch history - ✗ Tagging studies - ✗ Population surveys

What You DO Have: - ✓ Length measurements - ✓ Catch data - ✓ Basic life history - ✓ Landing information - ✓ Recent time series

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Why Length-Based Methods?
Length is Easy to Measure:


Simple equipment (measuring ruler)
Minimal training required
Immediate feedback
Low cost
High consistency


Length Contains Information:
Size distributions reveal: - Population age structure - Growth rates - Fishing pressure - Recruitment patterns

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Key Concept: Growth
Von Bertalanffy Growth Model:
Fish length increases over time following a curve:
\[L_t = L_∞ (1 - e^{-K(t-t_0)})\]
Where: - L∞: Asymptotic length (max size) - K: Growth rate (how fast) - t: Age - t₀: Age at length zero

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Length-Based Methods Overview
Three Main Approaches:


1. LBB Model Length-Based Bayesian - Estimates from data - Complex but flexible - Best when trained

2. LIME Model Length-Integrated Mixed Effects - Uses length frequencies - Integrated framework - Well-developed

3. Empirical Indicators Simple heuristics - Easy to calculate - Transparent - Immediate insights

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Empirical Indicators: Length Metrics
Mean Length:
Average size of fish in catch
mean_length <- data |>
  group_by(year) |>
  summarise(mean_L = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE))
Interpretation: - Increasing trend = good (growing population) - Decreasing trend = concern (overfishing)

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Empirical Indicators: L95 & Lmax
L95 (95th Percentile):
Size at which 95% of fish are smaller


Indicates presence of large fish
Decreasing L95 = concerning pattern
Vulnerable to sampling gaps


Lmax (Maximum Observed):
Largest fish in catch

Changes with sampling intensity
Indicator of recruitment & growth
Use cautiously (influenced by luck)

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Practical Example: Somali Data Analysis
Our Dataset Recap:

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Analysis 4: Growth Estimation
Length-Weight Relationships:
# Fit allometric model: W = a * L^b
growth_model <- lw |>
  filter(!is.na(length_cm), !is.na(weight_kg)) |>
  lm(log(weight_kg) ~ log(length_cm), data = .)

# Extract parameters
a <- exp(coef(growth_model)[1])
b <- coef(growth_model)[2]

# Interpretation: b ~= 3 (isometric growth)
# b < 3 = getting thinner as grow (poor condition)
# b > 3 = getting heavier as grow (good condition)

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Interpreting Length-Based Results
What Mean Length Tells Us:


Increasing Mean Length - ✓ Stock recovering - ✓ Good recruitment - ✓ Reduced fishing - ✓ Positive trend

Decreasing Mean Length - ✗ Fishing pressure high - ✗ Recruitment issues - ✗ Population aging - ✗ Negative trend

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Reference Points Concept
Management Targets:
Define desired stock conditions:


Target reference point (TRP): What we aim for
Limit reference point (LRP): Below this = risky
Precautionary approach: Stay well above LRP


Example from Data:
# Hypothetical reference points
target_mean_length <- 35  # cm
limit_mean_length <- 25   # cm

status <- mean_length |>
  mutate(
    risk = case_when(
      mean_L > target_mean_length ~ "Low",
      mean_L > limit_mean_length ~ "Medium",
      TRUE ~ "High"
    )
  )

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Uncertainty in Assessments
Sources of Uncertainty:


Data Uncertainty - Sampling bias - Measurement error - Incomplete coverage - Missing years

Model Uncertainty - Simplifying assumptions - Parameter estimates - Biological variability - Environmental factors

Best Practice:
Always communicate uncertainty with estimates!

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Decision-Making Under Uncertainty
Precautionary Principle:
When uncertain, be conservative:
# Don't just report point estimate
result <- tibble(
  estimate = 32.5,
  lower_ci = 30.2,
  upper_ci = 34.8,
  recommendation = "Maintain current effort, monitor closely"
)

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Stock Assessment Report Template
Minimum Contents:






Note


1. Executive Summary (1 paragraph) - Stock status: Green/Yellow/Red - Key findings - Main recommendation
2. Data & Methods (brief) - Data sources - Indicators used - Time period
3. Results (with figures) - Key metrics & trends - Comparisons with history
4. Conclusions - Stock status interpretation - Uncertainties - Management recommendations
5. References - Data sources - Methods citations

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Case Study: Example Report
Berbera Tuna Stock:






Important


Status: YELLOW (Caution)
Mean length declining 2.1 cm/year (2017-2023) - 2017: 37.2 cm - 2023: 34.5 cm
Interpretation: Increasing fishing pressure or recruitment declining
Recommendation: - Monitor closely next 6 months - Reduce catch if trend continues - Increase sampling frequency

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Communicating Results to Decision-Makers
Avoid Technical Jargon:
Instead of: > “The von Bertalanffy growth model shows K=0.28, indicating asymptotic length of 55cm…”
Say: > “Fish are growing to about 55cm maximum. They reach adult size at 5-6 years old.”

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Visualizations for Policy Makers
Keep It Simple:


One main message per chart
Use traffic light colors (Red/Yellow/Green)
Show trends clearly
Label axes in plain language
Include uncertainty (error bars)
Highlight key changes

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Management Actions Based on Assessment
Green Status Actions:
✓ Maintain current fishing levels
✓ Continue regular monitoring
✓ Share success with community
✓ Document best practices

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Management Actions: Yellow Status
Caution Response:
⚠ Reduce fishing effort by 10-20%
⚠ Increase monitoring frequency
⚠ Investigate cause of decline
⚠ Consult stakeholders

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Management Actions: Red Status
Urgent Response:
✗ Implement immediate catch reductions
✗ Restrict fishing areas or seasons
✗ Emergency data collection
✗ Convene management committee

Building Your Program:

Year 2-3: Annual assessments - Compare with baseline - Detect trends - Refine methods
Year 4+: Adaptive management - Adjust regulations - Scale sampling - Expand to new areas

text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid
Don’t:


Over-interpret single year changes
Ignore measurement uncertainty
Use methods beyond your understanding
Skip quality control checks
Extrapolate beyond data range
Report false precision
Ignore biological reality

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Welcome to Module 5
Data Analysis Methods


Learning Objectives

Master descriptive statistics
Apply statistical tests appropriately
Create publication-quality visualizations
Interpret results correctly
Communicate findings effectively


Why This Matters

Transforms clean data into insights
Statistics reveal patterns & trends
Visualizations communicate clearly
Proper interpretation prevents errors
Evidence-based decisions require rigor

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
The Analysis Framework
Five-Step Process:

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Step 1: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)
Understand Your Data Structure:
# Get overview
glimpse(data)
str(data)

# Check dimensions
dim(data)

# List variables and types
names(data)
data_types <- sapply(data, class)

# Quick summary
summary(data)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
EDA: Missing Data Inspection
Visualize Missing Patterns:
library(naniar)

# Summary of missing values
data |>
  miss_var_summary() |>
  arrange(desc(pct_miss))

# Visualize missing data pattern
vis_miss(data)

# Check if missingness is random
mcar_test(data)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Step 2: Descriptive Statistics
Central Tendency:
# Mean vs Median (robust to outliers)
data |>
  group_by(fish_group) |>
  summarise(
    mean_length = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    median_length = median(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n(),
    .groups = 'drop'
  )
Dispersion:
# Spread of data
data |>
  group_by(region) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    iqr = IQR(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),  # Interquartile range
    cv = sd / mean * 100,  # Coefficient of variation
    .groups = 'drop'
  )

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Comparing Multiple Groups: ANOVA
Testing Differences Across Regions:
# Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
anova_result <- data |>
  anova_test(length_cm ~ region)

anova_result

# If significant, which groups differ?
# Post-hoc test
data |>
  tukey_hsd(length_cm ~ region)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Correlation & Relationship Testing
Length-Weight Relationship:
# Pearson correlation
data |>
  cor_test(length_cm, weight_kg)

# Linear regression
model <- lm(weight_kg ~ length_cm, data = data)
summary(model)

# Extract coefficients
coef(model)  # Intercept & slope
r_squared <- summary(model)$r.squared

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Time Series Analysis: Trend Testing
Detecting Significant Trends:
# Prepare data
trend_data <- data |>
  group_by(year) |>
  summarise(
    mean_length = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n(),
    .groups = 'drop'
  )

# Linear regression for trend
trend_model <- lm(mean_length ~ year, data = trend_data)
summary(trend_model)

# Slope interpretation:
# Positive slope = increasing over time
# Negative slope = decreasing over time
# p-value < 0.05 = statistically significant

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Effect Size Interpretation
Practical vs Statistical Significance:
# Cohen's d for effect size (two groups)
data |>
  filter(region %in% c('Berbera', 'Mogadishu')) |>
  cohens_d(length_cm ~ region)

# Effect size interpretation:
# |d| < 0.2 = negligible
# |d| 0.2-0.5 = small
# |d| 0.5-0.8 = medium
# |d| > 0.8 = large

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Step 4: Visualization Best Practices
Plot Types by Purpose:


Distribution - Histogram - Density plot - Box plot - Violin plot
Relationship - Scatter plot - Line graph - Trend line

Comparison - Bar chart - Box plot - Dot plot - Slope graph
Composition - Stacked bar - Area chart - Pie chart (avoid!)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Step 5: Interpreting Results
Key Interpretation Principles:


Start with confidence intervals, not just p-values
Effect sizes matter more than statistical significance
Consider practical significance: Is 1cm difference meaningful?
Look at data visually before trusting statistics
Account for multiple testing (adjust p-values)
State assumptions clearly about your data
Acknowledge limitations and uncertainties

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
P-Values: Common Misinterpretations
What p-value DOES mean:
p = 0.03 means:
"If the null hypothesis is true, we'd see data 
this extreme 3% of the time by chance alone"
What p-value DOES NOT mean:
✗ Probability the result is true
✗ Probability the hypothesis is true
✗ How big the effect is
✗ How important the finding is

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Confidence Intervals vs P-Values
Better Approach:
# Instead of: "p < 0.05, significant difference"
# Report: "Mean difference: 5.2 cm (95% CI: 2.1 to 8.3 cm)"

# Calculate confidence intervals
data |>
  filter(region %in% c('Berbera', 'Mogadishu')) |>
  group_by(region) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    se = sd(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE) / sqrt(n()),
    ci_lower = mean - 1.96 * se,
    ci_upper = mean + 1.96 * se,
    .groups = 'drop'
  )

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Common Analysis Pitfalls
Avoid These Mistakes:


P-hacking: Testing many hypotheses until p < 0.05
Multiple comparisons: Adjust p-values for multiple tests
Ignoring assumptions: Check normality, homogeneity of variance
Extrapolation: Don’t predict beyond data range
Correlation ≠ causation: Relationships don’t prove causality
Publication bias: Negative results are also important
False precision: Report uncertainty appropriately

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Handling Multiple Comparisons
Correction Methods:
# Bonferroni correction (conservative)
alpha_adjusted <- 0.05 / number_of_tests

# FDR (false discovery rate) correction (liberal)
p_values <- c(0.001, 0.023, 0.045, 0.089, 0.12)
p_adjust(p_values, method = 'BH')  # Benjamini-Hochberg

# Built-in: Tukey HSD for multiple comparisons
data |>
  tukey_hsd(length_cm ~ region)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Regression: Understanding Assumptions
Before Running Linear Model:
# 1. Linearity: visual inspection
plot(data$length_cm, data$weight_kg)

# 2. Normality: residuals should be normal
model <- lm(weight_kg ~ length_cm, data = data)
shapiro.test(residuals(model))

# 3. Homogeneity of variance
data |>
  levene_test(weight_kg ~ region)

# 4. Independence: no autocorrelation
car::durbinWatsonTest(model)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Reporting Statistical Results
Standard Format:






Note


Good reporting: > “Mean length differed significantly between regions (F₂,₉₈ = 4.52, p = 0.013). Berbera fish were larger (M = 35.2, SD = 5.1) than Mogadishu (M = 32.1, SD = 4.8).”
Include: - Test statistic (F, t, χ²) - Degrees of freedom - P-value - Descriptive statistics (means, SDs) - Effect size when appropriate

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Creating Analysis Reports
R Markdown Template:
# file: analysis_report.Rmd
---
title: "Stock Assessment Report 2024"
author: "Data Analyst"
date: "2025-12-19"
output: html_document
---

# Executive Summary
Key findings and recommendations

# Methods
Data sources, analytical approaches

Figures and tables with interpretation

What do results mean?

# Conclusion
Recommendations for management

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Automating Analysis Reports
Generate Reports Programmatically:
# file: generate_regional_reports.R
regions <- unique(data$region)

for (region in regions) {
  regional_data <- filter(data, region == !!region)
  
  rmarkdown::render(
    'templates/regional_assessment.Rmd',
    params = list(region_name = region, region_data = regional_data),
    output_file = paste0('reports/', region, '_2024.html')
  )
}

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Sensitivity Analysis
Test Robustness of Results:
# Remove potential outliers and reanalyze
data_no_outliers <- data |>
  filter(length_cm > quantile(length_cm, 0.05, na.rm = TRUE),
         length_cm < quantile(length_cm, 0.95, na.rm = TRUE))

# Compare results
comparison <- tibble(
  analysis = c('Full data', 'Without outliers'),
  mean_length = c(
    mean(data$length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    mean(data_no_outliers$length_cm, na.rm = TRUE)
  ),
  trend = c(
    cor(data$year, data$length_cm, use = 'complete.obs'),
    cor(data_no_outliers$year, data_no_outliers$length_cm, use = 'complete.obs')
  )
)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Bayesian Alternative: Credible Intervals
Probabilistic Framework:
library(bayesplot)
library(rstanarm)

# Bayesian regression
bayes_model <- stan_glm(
  weight_kg ~ length_cm + fish_group,
  data = data,
  prior = normal(0, 2),
  chains = 4, iter = 2000
)

# Credible intervals (more intuitive than confidence intervals)
posterior_interval(bayes_model)

title: Presentation 10: Trophic Level
text:
Welcome to Presentation 10
Trophic Level: Understanding the Marine Food Web


Learning Objectives

Define what a trophic level is.
Understand its importance in fisheries management.
Learn about “fishing down the food web.”
Calculate the Mean Trophic Index of the catch.


Why This Matters

Provides an ecosystem-level view of fishing impacts.
A key indicator for Ecosystem-Based Fisheries Management (EBFM).
Helps detect long-term changes in the marine environment.

title: Presentation 10: Trophic Level
text:
What is a Trophic Level?
A trophic level is the position an organism occupies in a food chain. It represents a “step” in the flow of energy.

Level 1: Primary Producers (e.g., Phytoplankton) - Create their own food.
Level 2: Primary Consumers (Herbivores, e.g., Zooplankton) - Eat producers.
Level 3: Secondary Consumers (Carnivores, e.g., Mackerel) - Eat primary consumers.
Level 4: Tertiary Consumers (Carnivores, e.g., Tuna) - Eat secondary consumers.
Level 5: Apex Predators (e.g., large Sharks) - Top of the food chain.

title: Presentation 10: Trophic Level
text:
The Marine Food Web
In reality, it’s a complex web, not a simple chain. A single species can feed at multiple trophic levels.

Source: Arreguín-Sánchez (2014)

title: Presentation 10: Trophic Level
text:
Why is Trophic Level Important?

Ecosystem Health Indicator: The average trophic level of the catch can signal major shifts in the ecosystem.
“Fishing Down the Food Web”: This is a classic sign of overfishing. Fisheries first deplete large, high-trophic-level predators and then shift to targeting smaller, lower-trophic-level species.
Management Strategy: High-trophic-level species (like sharks) are often long-lived and slow to reproduce, requiring more conservative management than low-trophic-level species (like sardines).

title: Presentation 10: Trophic Level
section: Calculating Mean Trophic Index (MTI) of the Catch
text:
Calculating Mean Trophic Index (MTI) of the Catch
We can estimate the health of the fishery by tracking the average trophic level of the fish we catch over time.
Step 1: Assign Trophic Levels to Fish Groups
We use known values from sources like FishBase.

trophic_levels <- tibble::tribble(
  ~fish_group,       ~trophic_level,
  "Tuna",            4.4,
  "Shark",           4.5,
  "Billfish",        4.5,
  "Jacks",           3.9,
  "Mackerel",        3.6,
  "Rays and Skates", 3.5,
  "Other",           3.7  # Average assumption
)

title: Presentation 10: Trophic Level
Presentation 10: Trophic Level
text:
Key Takeaways

Trophic level is a fundamental concept for understanding an organism’s role in the ecosystem.
Tracking the Mean Trophic Index (MTI) of the catch is a powerful, simple indicator of ecosystem health.
A declining MTI is a classic sign of “fishing down the food web,” indicating unsustainable pressure on top predators.
This analysis is a core component of Ecosystem-Based Fisheries Management (EBFM).

title: Presentation 10: Trophic Level
text:

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
section: Introduction to Length-Based Stock Assessment Models
text:
Introduction to Length-Based Stock Assessment Models


Learning Objectives

 Understand why length-based models are used in data-limited fisheries.
 Learn the key inputs for the LBSPR model.
 Run a basic LBSPR analysis in R.
 Interpret the main outputs: SPR and F/M.


Why This Matters

 These are the most practical and powerful tools for your data.
 Provides a quantitative estimate of stock status.
 Directly informs management about fishing pressure.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
What is a “Fish Stock”?
Before we model, we must understand what we are assessing.

“

A group of fish of the same species that live in a particular geographic area and mix enough to share a common gene pool

”


Understanding the stock is the first step. The model’s results apply only to the stock we define.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Critical Assumptions


1. Stock Boundaries
Scientific Basis: The assessed population represents a self-sustaining unit with minimal immigration or emigration.
Practical Implication: Fish movement between regions must be negligible relative to population size.
2. Fishing as Primary Driver
Scientific Basis: Population dynamics are driven by natural mortality and fishing mortality, not by migration patterns.
Practical Implication: Changes in stock size reflect fishing pressure, not population shifts.

3. Representative Sampling
Scientific Basis: Length distributions in catches accurately represent the population structure.
Practical Implication: Sampling must be unbiased and cover the full spatial and temporal range of the fishery.






For This Training


We will assess yellowfin tuna caught in Somali waters as a discrete stock, recognizing this is a simplification that may require refinement for formal assessments.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Why Use Length-Based Models?
The Challenge of Data-Limited Fisheries
Many developing-nation fisheries lack:

Age-reading laboratories and trained personnel
Long-term catch and effort time series
Comprehensive biological sampling programs
Resources for expensive aging techniques (otolith reading)

The Solution: Length-Based Analysis
Advantages:

Length data is relatively easy and inexpensive to collect
Measurements can be taken dockside without specialized equipment
Large sample sizes are feasible with minimal resources
Well-established theoretical foundation







Core Assumption


The length distribution in your catch sample must reflect the length distribution in the exploited population. Biased sampling (e.g., only large fish, one gear type) will compromise results.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
What is LBSPR Model Framework
Length-Based Spawning Potential Ratio is a stock assessment model that estimates reproductive capacity under current fishing pressure.

Developed by Hordyk et al. (2015)
Based on equilibrium life history theory
Uses size-structured population dynamics
Validated across multiple species and fisheries

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
LBSPR Model Framework Model Outputs
Primary Metric: SPR (Spawning Potential Ratio)

Proportion of unfished reproductive potential remaining
Values range from 0 (collapsed) to 1 (unfished)
Directly comparable to management reference points

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Interpreting SPR Values








SPR Range
Stock Status
Management Implication




> 0.40
Healthy
Current fishing sustainable


0.20 - 0.40
Moderately exploited
Monitor closely, consider precautionary measures


< 0.20
Overfished
Urgent management action required

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Reference Points

Target: SPR = 40% (widely used globally)
Limit: SPR = 20% (conservation threshold)
These values may be adjusted based on species-specific characteristics and management objectives

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Key Inputs for LBSPR
To run LBSPR, we need two main things:



📊 Length Frequency Data: A representative sample of the lengths of fish caught from the stock.
🧬 Life History Parameters:

Linf: Asymptotic length (the theoretical maximum size).
MK: The ratio of natural mortality (M) to the growth rate (K).
L50: Length at 50% maturity.
L95: Length at 95% maturity.



These parameters can often be found on FishBase.org for your species or a similar one.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Parameters needed - 1 Biology



von Bertalanffy asymptotic length (Linf)
M/K ratio (natural mortality divided by von Bertalanffy K coefficient) (MK)
Length at 50% maturity (L50)
Length at 95% maturity (L95)




Code
MyPars@Linf <- 100 
MyPars@L50 <- 66 
MyPars@L95 <- 70
MyPars@MK <- 1.5

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Parameters needed - 2 Exploitation



Length at 50% selectivity (SL50)
Length at 95% selectivity (SL95)
F/M ratio (FM) or SPR (SPR).


If you specify both, the F/M value will be ignored.




Code
MyPars@SL50 <- 50 
MyPars@SL95 <- 65
MyPars@SPR <- 0.4

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Parameters needed - 3 Size Classes



Width of the length classes (BinWidth)
Maximum length of the sample (BinMax)
Minimum length of sample (BinMin)
Units for the length parameters




Code
MyPars@BinWidth <- 5
MyPars@BinMax <- 150
MyPars@BinMin <- 0

MyPars@L_units <- "mm"

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Interpreting LBSPR Output
The model provides three key estimates:

SPR (Spawning Potential Ratio):

The plot shows an estimated SPR.
It inform on the state of the stock.
A common target is 40% and a limit is 20%.

F/M (Fishing Mortality / Natural Mortality):

The estimated F/M ratio.
It tells us how intense fishing mortality is relative to natural death.
An F/M ratio > 1.0 suggests that fishing is causing more deaths than natural causes, a sign of high fishing pressure.

The fish state-stock:

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Key Takeaways

Length-based models like LBSPR are powerful tools for assessing data-limited stocks.
They require length frequency data and some basic life history parameters.
The key outputs, SPR and F/M, provide a quantitative snapshot of stock status and fishing pressure.
These results can directly inform management actions, such as deciding whether to increase, decrease, or maintain current fishing effort.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Questions & Discussion
Thank You

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Step 1: Prepare the Length Data
First, we need to process our raw data into the format LBSPR requires: a simple vector of fish lengths. We will filter for our target species group, “Tuna”, and remove any invalid length measurements.




Code
# Filter for Tuna and select the length column
tuna_lengths <- lw |> 
  filter(
    fish_group == "Tuna",
    !is.na(length_cm)
  ) |> 
  pull(length_cm)

# How many fish do we have?

tuna_lengths |> 
length()

# Let's look at the first few lengths
tuna_lengths |> 
head()

tuna_lengths |> 
  range()



It’s always a good idea to visualize your length data with a histogram before running the model. This helps you spot any potential issues with the data.


Code
hist(tuna_lengths, 
     main = "Length Frequency of Tuna",
     xlab = "Length (cm)",
     breaks = 30)

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Step 1 : Create LBSPR Objects




Code
MyPars <- new("LB_pars")




The LB_pars object has 25 slots.
Not all parameters need to be specified for the simulation model.



Code
MyPars |> slotNames()

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Step 2: Populate
Now, we populate the LB_pars object with key metric


Code
# Biological
# MyPars$Species = "Yellowfin"
MyPars@Linf <- 100 
MyPars@L50 <- 66 
MyPars@L95 <- 70
MyPars@MK <- 1.5 

# Exploitation

MyPars@SL50 <- 50 
MyPars@SL95 <- 65
MyPars@SPR <- 0.4

# Size Classes

MyPars@BinWidth <- 5
MyPars@BinMax <- 150
MyPars@BinMin <- 0
MyPars@L_units <- "mm"

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Step 3: Run the LBSPR Model
With our parameters and lengths objects ready, we can now run the LBSPRfit function. This is the core of the analysis, where the model fits the parameters to the length data to estimate the stock status.


Code
# Fit the LBSPR model
lbspr_fit <- MyPars |> 
  LBSPR::LBSPRsim()


The lbspr_fit object now contains all the results of our analysis.

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
section: Step 4: View and Plot the Results
text:
Step 4: View and Plot the Results
The model provides estimates for selectivity (SL50, SL95), fishing pressure (F/M), and most importantly, the stock status (SPR).


You can view the key estimated parameters directly from the fitted object.


Code
lbspr_fit@Ests



The plotSim function gives a comprehensive visual summary of the fit


Code
lbspr_fit |> 
plotSim()

title: Introduction to Length-Based Models
text:
Interpreting the Real Output
Let’s look at the plot from our lbspr_fit object.
!{fig-align=“center” width=“80%”}

Left Panel: Shows the fit of the model (red line) to your observed length data (grey bars). A good fit means the line follows the general shape of the bars.
Right Panel: This is the key result. It shows the estimated SPR (Spawning Potential Ratio). The black dot is the estimate, and the grey area is the uncertainty. You can compare this value directly to your management targets (e.g., 40%) and limits (e.g., 20%).

Based on this output, you can make a clear statement about the stock’s status.

title: Training Needs Assessment

Purpose

Goal: To design an effective stock assessment training program for Somali fisheries professionals.
Objective: Identify current knowledge gaps and specific training priorities through a targeted needs assessment.
Rationale: This data-driven approach ensures the curriculum is relevant, practical, and directly addresses the needs of the participants.

title: Training Needs Assessment

Our Approach

A structured questionnaire was developed to capture participant backgrounds and self-assessed skill levels.
The questionnaire was distributed for completion.
The collected data was downloaded and analyzed to identify capacity gaps and training priorities.

title: Training Needs Assessment

Proposed Training Module








Proposed Training Curriculum


Directly informed by the Training Needs Assessment


Module
Rationale
Key Content




Module 1: Fundamentals & Concepts
Reinforce core knowledge, as many participants rate themselves as 'Basic' or 'Moderate'.
Stock assessment principles, data types, and their application.


Module 2: Data Collection Protocols
A high-priority area. Address gaps in sampling design, quality control, and catch/effort data handling.
Practical exercises on designing sampling schemes and ensuring data quality.


Module 3: Data-Limited Methods
The most requested component and the area with the lowest self-assessed expertise (modeling).
Focus on length-based models, empirical methods, and practical application using R.
